intro: Coffea brasiliensis, commonly known as the Brazilian coffee tree, is a species native to the tropical regions of South America. It is a small evergreen tree that can grow up to 10 meters tall, characterized by its glossy dark green leaves and fragrant white flowers. The plant produces red, fleshy berries that contain two seeds, which are the coffee beans used for brewing. It thrives in humid, shaded environments with well-drained soil and requires consistent moisture. The botanical features of Coffea brasiliensis make it well-suited for cultivation in tropical and subtropical climates.
